feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:58PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
A vigorous low pressure system will drop into Arizona Thursday into Friday with a strong surface cold front sliding down the eastern plains. Windy conditions will develop quickly Thursday night into Friday as the cold front surges westward and accelerates through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will create potentially damaging wind gusts up to 65 mph in east Albuquerque, especially near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Winds will remain strong and gusty through the day Friday and into Friday evening before tapering off by Saturday morning. Gusts will not be quite as strong in western areas of the Albuquerque metro area, but will still be gusty.
Residents and travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days, and make preparations to store loose items such as lawn furniture, trampolines and other items that might become airborne in the strong winds. Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Middle Rio Grande Valley/Albuquerque Metro Area

cap:parameter.value: STRONG TO POTENTIALLY DAMAGING WINDS EXPECTED IN EASTERN ALBUQUERQUE

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 12 at 1:56PM AKDT until March 14 at 7:00AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...POSSIBLE HEAVY SNOW FOR HAINES AND KLONDIKE HIGHWAYS...
.A band of heavy precipitation is set to impact the panhandle Wednesday night into Thursday. In the far northern panhandle at elevation, temperatures are expected to remain cold enough to allow for accumulating snow along the highways, while at sea level temperatures will warm with southerly flow.
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 9 inches possible.
* WHERE...Haines and Klondike Highways.
* WHEN...From Wednesday evening through Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snowfall rates expected early Thursday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 2:52PM PDT by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
At 251 PM PDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Weippe, or 10 miles southeast of Orofino, moving northeast at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Visibility one-half mile or less and wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Low visibility could result in dangerous driving conditions. Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Orofino, Pierce, Weippe, Cardiff, Jaype, and Woodland.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Clearwater Mountains; Orofino/Grangeville Region

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 12 at 3:25PM MDT until March 13 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING WEDNESDAY NOON TO 7 PM FOR THE EAST CENTRAL PLAINS DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Strengthening flow aloft ahead of a powerful storm system, and an area of surface low pressure near the southeast corner of Colorado, will produce strong southwest winds over the east central plains Wednesday afternoon until sunset. Humidities will also plummet near and below 15 percent as high temperatures climb a few to around 10 degrees above normal.
* AREA AND TIMING...East Central Plains (Zone 126) Wednesday from noon to 7 PM MDT.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 20 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph, except up to 50 mph on the Caprock.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping between 11 and 18 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 7 PM MDT WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 4:16PM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
Southwest winds gusting to 30 mph and relative humidity as low as 25 percent has resulted in elevated fire danger. This will continue through sunset or through around 8 PM. The windy and dry conditions ignite grass or brush fires. Several field fires were reported in progress by a National Weather Service Meteorologist, along Interstate 74, near Brownsburg.
Exercise extreme caution with any outdoor burning or open flames and with the disposal of smoking materials.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 12 at 3:50PM EDT until March 13 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey...
Passaic River At Little Falls affecting Essex and Passaic Counties.
For the Passaic River...including Little Falls...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River at Little Falls.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 5.5 feet, The lower end of East-Holsman Street in Paterson, closest to the river, begins to flood. At 6.0 feet, Portions of Hoffman Grove in Wayne sustain some nuisance flooding. At 6.5 feet, Low lying areas in the vicinity of Two Bridges in Wayne are flooded. The lower end of Bergen Street in Paterson, closest to the river, begins to flood. At 7.0 feet, Minor flooding begins in Lincoln Park, Wayne and Little Falls. At 8.0 feet, Flooding occurs in the "Old" Wayne area of Wayne. The recycling center and Wagaraw Road ball field complex in Hawthorne begins to experience flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:30 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 7.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:30 PM EDT Tuesday was 7.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage just after midnight tonight and continue falling to 5.4 feet early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.3 feet on 03/23/2003. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey...

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River above Singac.
* WHEN...Until early Thursday morning.

The Pequannock River Park also floods. At 9.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield is subject to closures. At 9.5 feet, Camp Lane and Marginal Road in Fairfield begins to flood. At 10.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield begins to flood. Finns Drive, Siesta Drive, and Market street in Wayne are all susceptible to flooding. William Street, Louis Street, and Zeliff Avenue in Little Falls can begin to flood. Portions of Lincoln Park become impassable. The Meadows Golf Club in Lincoln Park floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 PM EDT Tuesday the stage was 9.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 PM EDT Tuesday was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon and continue falling to 7.1 feet early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 12/23/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 1:17PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
A cold frontal boundary will push through the western half of Utah later this afternoon through the mid-to-late evening hours. Along this boundary, a line of moderate to heavy precipitation is expected, mostly in the form of rain. There is a low chance (25 percent likelihood) that a transition to snow occurs in the areas of heavier precipitation rates as the boundary moves through. The most likely period that this would occur will be between 5 PM and 7PM along the I-80 corridor west of the Tooele Valley, 7 PM and 10 PM along the Wasatch Front, and between 9 PM to 12AM along the I-15 corridor between Nephi and Cedar City.
Scenario 1 (most likely): The frontal boundary pushes through the western half of Utah, bringing moderate to high intensity precipitation in the form of rain across all areas. Snow may mix in toward the end of the banded precipitation, however, significant accumulations of snowfall will not be expected.
Scenario 2 (less likely): The frontal boundary pushes through the western half of Utah. bringing high intensity precipitation rates that force snow levels down to valley floors. If this occurs, disruptions to travel are likely along the I-80 and I-15 corridors, especially on the higher elevation passes. Possible snow accumulations with a rapid transition to snowfall will be 1 to 3 inches. Again, this is a low probability event (about 25 percent chance or less).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Great Salt Lake Desert and Mountains; Tooele and Rush Valleys; Northern Wasatch Front; Salt Lake Valley; Utah Valley; Western Millard and Juab Counties; Eastern Juab/Millard Counties; Southwest Utah

cap:parameter.value: Potential for rapid transition to snowfall in heavy precipitation late this afternoon and evening

entry.summary:
NEAR CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS TODAY FOR PORTIONS OF EAST CENTRAL AND NORTHEAST MINNESOTA...
Dry conditions and breezy winds will lead to near critical fire weather conditions today. Northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph with gusts around 20 mph are forecast today. A few higher gusts will be possible. The strongest winds along the North Shore. Minimum relative humidity values of 15 to 30 percent are also expected. Together, these conditions could lead to the rapid spread of fires.
Check burning restrictions and fire danger before burning. For more information on burning restrictions for Minnesota, see www.dnr.state.mn.us/forestry/fire/firerating_restrictions.html.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:29AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: Cold air in place over the far northern inner channels, Glacier Bay, and the northeast Gulf Coast will be over run by a front with considerable moisture on Wednesday night. Snow from this front is forecast to begin early on Wednesday and increase in intensity through the day. Peak snowfall rates are expected during the night Wednesday night, then diminish rapidly on Thursday morning. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected along the Haines and Klondike highways. There is lower confidence in snow totals for Yakutat due to the possibility of stronger southerly push behind the front raising temperatures high enough to limit accumulation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan

cap:parameter.value: POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY ACCUMULATING SNOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:29AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Long range computer models are coming into agreement about a moderate to heavy rain event for the middle of the week. The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area, with the heaviest rates expected Wednesday night into Thursday. Current 24 hour precipitation totals for the panhandle from Wednesday morning through Thursday morning range from 1 to 2.5 inches, with the highest totals along the outer coast and southern panhandle. By the end of the work week, the plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend. Snowmelt at higher elevations will add to the heavy precipitation near sea level that may result in flooding along creeks, streams, and rivers. Ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage may also become an issue.
We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: WARMING TEMPERATURES WITH PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN BEGINNING IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS WEEK

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Charlotteville affecting Toombs, Jeff Davis and Montgomery Counties.
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Wayne and Long Counties.

* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Charlotteville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Bankfull conditions occur along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Some flooding begins in low lying areas around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage in south Montgomery County. The water will approach portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 13.0 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding occurs in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water reaches the top of the public boat ramp by the bridge. Flood waters expand in low lying areas in south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will begin to cover portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 14.0 feet, Minor flooding continues in the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water covers the low portion and entrance of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. The public boat ramp is under two feet of water. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding expands into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. The water will be one to two feet deep over portions of Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge. Flood waters continue to expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 2 to 4 feet over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 18.0 feet, Minor flooding expands further into the woodlands along the river upstream and downstream from the gage on the U.S. Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will completely cover Towns Bluff Lane by the bridge and begin to flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flood waters expand further into south Montgomery County around 1.5 miles upstream from the gage. The water will be 4 to 6 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane... Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. At 19.0 feet, Minor flooding expands upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters near 3 feet deep cover Towns Bluff Lane and flood the slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery County with the water 5 to 7 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The water reaches the top of boat ramps and parking lots will begin to flood in Towns Bluff Park and along the end of Uvalda Landing Road in Jeff Davis County. At 20.0 feet, Moderate flooding begins. Significant flooding occurs upstream and downstream from the Highway 221 bridge. Flood waters will be near 4 feet deep on Towns Bluff Lane and flood the concrete slab foundations of the elevated homes. Flooding expands further into Montgomery county with the water 6 to 8 feet deep over large portions of Three Rivers Lane...Altamaha River Road and Ogle Sandbar Road. The parking lot at Towns Bluff Park and portions of Uvalda Landing Road will be flooded in Jeff Davis County.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:15 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 15.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Forecast...The river may fall a little bit more today before rising to a crest of around 16.0 feet by tonight or Wednesday. It will then fall below flood stage early Thursday morning. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.1 feet on 04/04/2003. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 4:17AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
Mountain snow and lower elevation rain showers will spread across western and northern NM Wednesday, creating slick travel above 8,000 feet. Conditions deteriorate Thursday and Friday as a strong backdoor cold front surges down the eastern plains and funnels through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will drop snow levels down to near valley floors and create damaging wind gusts up to 70 mph in east Albuquerque near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Gusty east winds combined with moderate to locally heavy snowfall rates could also create blizzard-like conditions along I-40 through Tijeras Canyon and over the Continental Divide along US-550 and I-40. Significant snowfall accumulations and patchy blowing snow will create hazardous travel conditions elsewhere in the high terrain of western and northern New Mexico Thursday and Friday, particularly over mountain passes. Slick travel may linger into the weekend and early next week, although confidence is lower given the high storm track uncertainty. Travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days.
Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates. You may also monitor road conditions online at nmroads.com, via telephone at 1-800-432-4269, or by dialing 5-1-1 in New Mexico.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:52AM EDT by NWS Marquette MI
entry.summary:
Gusty west to northwest winds as high 15 to 20 mph this afternoon, combined with dry and warm conditions and a lack of recent rainfall will lead to elevated wildfire potential today across the interior west half of Upper Michigan.
Avoid any outdoor burning today. Immediately report any wildfires to local emergency services by calling 911.
Burn restrictions remain in effect. For complete details, visit www.dnr.state.mi.us/burnpermits, or by calling 866-922-2876.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:37AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Recent dry conditions, warming temperatures, increasing southwest to west winds and low relative humidity will result in elevated fire weather conditions across north-central, northeast and central Wisconsin this afternoon. The main concern will be in grassy areas.
Persons are urged to be careful with any activities that could potentially lead to a wildland fire. Campfires, outdoor grills, smoking materials, chain saws, and all-terrain vehicles all have the potential to throw a spark and ignite a wildfire.
Debris burning is the number one cause of wildfires in Wisconsin. Contact the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources to check on any burning restrictions that may be in place in your area.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 2:42AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
The combination of very low relative humidity values, warm temperatures, and dry fuels will result in elevated fire weather conditions this afternoon across southeast Minnesota and southwest into central Wisconsin. Afternoon relative humidity values fall to 15 to 25 percent with winds veering from the west to the northwest through the afternoon. West of the Mississippi River, wind speeds will be 5 to 10 mph with an occasional gust to 15 mph. East of the river, wind speeds will be 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 20 mph.
Under these conditions, fires will start and spread easily. Please exercise caution with any activities that involve outdoor fires or create sparks, including campfires, grilling, and operating large equipment. Cigarettes should be disposed of and extinguished properly. Please heed any local burn bans.
